- I'm driving down the road
and I look in my mirror

2.90.text: and there is a car right on my bumper.

8.17.text:
This would annoy me under
normal circumstances,

11.96.text:
the car has been designed
so it obviously has a face.

15.35.text: And not just a face, but a mean face,

18.11.text: and it was if some overbearing jerk

22.06.text:
is standing right behind
me to intimidate me.

34.90.text:
For example, people see
faces all over the place.

38.04.text: Electrical outlets seem to have faces,

40.43.text: you'll see them in clouds, and on trees,

44.01.text: but it goes beyond physical form.

46.07.text: It can also go to an inner life,

47.95.text:
where you think something
has thoughts and emotions

53.55.text:
- The '80s called, they
want their store back.

57.96.text:
- Tell me, what's the
secret of your syrup recipe?

60.00.text:
- I see you bought the
industrial size bottle

70.19.text:
in which they have something
nonhuman talk to us.

75.09.text:
- For over 75 years, people
have saved money with geckos.

81.81.text:
- We compared how persuasive
an advertisement was

84.92.text: when it had a real person talking versus

87.15.text:
something like a talking lamp,
an anthropomorphised entity.

91.04.text: We found an array of people

93.36.text:
from being highly
trusting of other people,

98.10.text: down to fully mistrustful of people.

103.37.text: it didn't matter who was talking to them.

106.18.text:
and they barely notice
who's talking to them.

110.66.text:
But the people who are really
low in interpersonal trust

116.95.text: that when a person starts talking to them,

119.62.text:
it's like a trigger in
their head that says,

121.41.text: "Oh people, they're not to be trusted,"

123.69.text:
and they don't believe
much of what's said.

126.66.text:
If you take that person out,
and put in a talking lamp,

130.93.text:
the message just kinda
gets in under the radar,

134.44.text: and people who are low in trust

136.20.text: are more persuaded by nonhuman things.

144.05.text: - It says here Hank's a real gas-guzzler.

150.60.text: - The way people react to these things

151.90.text: go way beyond just getting their attention

156.66.text:
It turns out if you present
a disease just as a disease,

162.28.text:
if I feel socially
powerful or socially weak,

166.78.text:
But if I make the disease seem
like an evil crime family,

171.85.text: think of the family of skin cancer,

174.98.text:
well now, thinking about
that disease as people

179.56.text:
intersects with how I feel
about how well I do with people.

183.69.text:
And if people feel sort
of large and in charge,

186.64.text: I'm not intimidated by other people,

189.22.text:
they actually think they're
less likely to get the disease

192.54.text:
and if they did get it, they'd
be able to fight it off.

195.51.text:
So when we're all the time
saying, "I'm gonna fight cancer

199.29.text: "and you're not gonna have my way."

201.96.text: That's not a cost-less sort of thing.

204.42.text: People who felt large and in charge

206.37.text: and could have their way with cancer

208.44.text:
were less likely to take
precautions to prevent it,

211.30.text:
like putting on a hat
or putting on sunscreen.

218.67.text:
- So, another phenomenon
we've seen in people,

221.93.text: not talking about products or brands,

226.09.text:
we found that if I think
about a social group

232.40.text:
I'll start to take on
their characteristics.

237.14.text:
in which we were looking
at different reactions

240.21.text: to thinking about Krispy Kreme as a person

242.99.text: or the brand Kellogg as a person.

245.96.text: We asked people would they be more likely

248.38.text: to take the elevator or the stairs,

250.72.text:
and if they're thinking
about Kellogg as a person,

255.65.text: the little fitness trainer of Kellogg,

258.53.text:
and they say, "Oh, yes,
I'd take the stairs,"

261.31.text:
but if they're thinking
Krispy Kreme as a person,

265.01.text:
they think, "Oh, that's
my little indulgent buddy,

266.82.text:
"we'll just take it easy here
and wait for the elevator."

272.13.text:
it's not just thinking about
the brand characteristics.

274.90.text:
If we had people think
about Kellogg all by itself,

277.92.text: or Krispy Kreme all by itself,

280.05.text: we didn't pick up any differences

281.54.text: in willingness to take the stairs.

283.51.text:
It required that they
think about it as a person.

299.73.text: It's part of a big Italian family.

303.19.text:
- What's important to
stress in all of this

304.91.text: is these responses are not being driven

309.97.text:
From birth, you learn how to
behave relative to other people

314.08.text: so what happens when you anthropomorphise

316.68.text: is it brings to mind, in an automatic way,

321.07.text:
the way you should act
around other people.

323.44.text: And so when products are products,

325.09.text: you react to them like things.

326.69.text:
When products are given
human characteristics,

329.08.text: you react to them like humans,

330.96.text: all without thinking about it very much.

333.40.text:
And that's where you get these
really remarkable effects

339.00.text:
start having profound
effects on our judgements

342.39.text: because we've misapplied humanity to them.

358.25.text: - Many of you feel bad for this lamp.

361.87.text:
It has no feelings and the
new one is much better.
